awd_abstract_narration:
This project will further the understanding of symmetries as a fundamental tool to organize structures in mathematics. The PI will bring new methods and results in representation theory, which is the mathematical study of symmetries via linear algebra, using higher categorical and homotopical methods. In the process, the PI will develop new computational approaches and new combinatorial objects are expected to arise.
 
This project will topologically enhance classical structures in algebra in order to analyze symmetries and fixed points, with the ultimate aim of resolving some fundamental questions in representation theory. A key goal of the project is to make progress in the understanding of simple modules and decomposition matrices of finite groups of Lie type using perverse equivalences. The PI will work toward a proof of Broue's abelian defect group conjecture via Deligne-Lusztig varieties. This will require developing new homotopical methods to deal with certain fixed point constructions. The PI will also investigate genericity properties and look for combinatorial objects to encode numerical information.

por.por_cntn:
This project was devoted to the development of new methods in the representation theory of finite groups and algebraic groups. One of the main directions concerned the use of higher symmetries: instead of vector spaces, higher representations involve actions on categories.


In a joint work with Andrew Manion, I initiated the higher representation theory of the super general Linear Lie algebra over a two-dimensional space. Our theory recovers the invariants associated to surfaces in Heegaard-Floer theory. This case will be a guide for the more difficult case of usual simple Lie algebras.
With Olivier Dudas, I have developed a new framework for modular representations of finite groups of Lie type. This involves decomposition matrices with two parameters. We have proposed and tested a conjecture involving Hilbert schemes of points and Macdonald polynomials in the case of unitary groups. This involved homological, homotopical, geometrical and combinatorial aspects, as well as the development and the optimization of computer programs.
For applications to modular representations of finite groups, it is necessary to develop the higher representation theory of toroidal algebras. This fits within the general framework of affinizing $2$-Kac-Moody algebras. The geometric construction of 2-representations of affinized quantum groups should involve coherent sheaves. As a first step, I have proposed that Verma modules and finite-dimensional simple representations of finite-dimensional simple Lie algebras should be obtained from coherent sheaves on spaces of quasi-maps in the flag variety. I have proved that this in the case for sl2. This opens the way for an understanding of higher representations via coherent sheaves compatible with affinization, while the previous constructions involved constructible sheaves.
